--- Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...> wrote:
> I guess I didn't understand your proposal; I'm not
> sure I do now.  Are you suggesting that we only
> inform
> the ANN of changes to the tablaeu of card?  

Yes, something like that.  I'm suggesting that the
inputs to the network each turn are only for the two
positions on the tableau that it is "choosing".

For example, with the following tableau:

1  3  1
3  2  2

As you suggested, you could either start out by
inputting the values for two random positions, or you
could always start in the upper left corner.

And let's stick with your binary representation.  The
values of the cards could be represented by two input
nodes:

Card value of 1: 1 0
Card value of 2: 0 1
Card value of 3: 1 1

To represent an occupied space or not you only need
one input node:

No card present: 0
Card present:    1

To represent the position on the tableau, you could
also use binary representation, e.g. with two rows and
three columns, as above, you could use:

X1: 0 0
X2: 0 1
X3: 1 0

Y1: 0
Y2: 1

Using this representation scheme, you would have six
input nodes for each position on the tableau (2 for
the value of the card, 1 for whether or not there is a
card, 2 for the X coordinate, and 1 for the Y
coordinate), and you only need to input two tableau
positions each turn, so your neural net only needs 12
inputs.

The outputs would be the X and Y coordinates of the
next two positions to pick, so you would need a total
of 6 outputs.
 
> This is a
> new idea; maybe it has merit.  

Well, it's not really a new idea. :)

Check out the message archives for this forum.  See
Darren Izzard's first message (#8), and the ensuing
"Shape Recognition" thread.  Similar idea.
  
> It seems like we
> would
> be increasing the memory burden, but maybe this
> would work.  

Yes, but that's exactly what you want to test, right?
:)  It would be interesting to experimentally contrast
this representation scheme with one in which the
entire tableau is input each turn.

> Do I understand you correctly now, that the idea is
> to tell the ANN all the changes that occur, instead
> of the current state of the table?

Not precisely, but I think I've explained it a little
better now.

That's the basic approach, but the ANN could "look at"
a given position on the tableau more than once, so
it's not as if it's restricted only to information
that is different each turn.

Does this make sense?

Derek
